title: Adjustable mount for laser module
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This thing will hold a laser module pointed in a certain direction.
I use two of them mounted on adjacent sides of my 3D printer, to ensure that the build platform is level. I first take the platform to the home position (the one it assumes while it waits for the extruder to heat up). Then I move both lasers so that they meet exactly at the platform's corner, and it's only one bright dot, not two. Then I move the platform around. If it's level, I see only a single dot all the time.

• (optional) Use a 3mm tap to thread the small hole in the truncated sphere and the one in the circular section of the main body.
  • Place the laser module in the truncated sphere's large through hole, and secure it in place with a short M3 bolt.
  • Put the main body's beam trough the secondary body's bracket. Make sure to orient it so that the inner sides of the circular sections form a cradle.
  • Place the truncated sphere inside the cradle, and close the cradle.
  • Use an M3 bolt to join the holes in the circular section of each body. This bolt will allow you to tighten or loosen the cradle's grip on the truncated sphere
  • Use two M3 bolts to secure the main body's beam to a suitable surface

description.text:
Weighted Companion Cube from the Portal remixed for easy printing without supports, outer dimensions are 5x5x5 cm (~2x2x2 in).

It is hollow and can serve as a box for small things, the top lid has a press-fit. Use a small file or sandpaper to slightly flatten the sides if needed for desired fit.

There is also a stencil, that can be used for spray painting gray parts on each side.Just snap the stencil on a cube's side and paint, it will block white areas. You can print the whole stencil, or just about 1 cm in height and use some plastic (on the photo) to cover rest of the cube, you will save time & filament.

title: Tangram -- Old game with a rethink of 3d Print

description.text:
The tangram had already been around in China for a long time when it was first brought to America by Captain M. Donnaldson, on his ship, Trader, in 1815. When it docked in Canton, the captain was given a pair of Sang-Hsia-koi's (author) Tangram books from 1815.[5] They were then brought with the ship to Philadelphia, where it docked in February 1816. The first Tangram book to be published in America was based on the pair brought by Donnaldson.
-- wikipedia
I am always felt nostalgic about those games that we play during our time (60s). Back then, we are poor and have not much of toys to play with. This Tangram, although was not as popular as Lego, but was intuative and mind thinking as anybody could imagine.
There were only 12 thingiverse members posted the tangram. Being the 13th member, I added a tray to house the 7 pieces together.
You could google "Tangram" for images and will see lots of styles and patterns you could think of. Have fun and print a copy for your kids (4 and above) to play with. Anthony L (MILKA)

For those with MakerBot Replicator 2 or 2X. Print with 0.3 layer height will do. I have filleted the edge of each corner with 1mm radius. So your printing should be smooth. Post me any comments if you need to know. Thanks
Anthony L (MILKA)

remixed_from.title: 8 to 12 GHz Horn antenna with Coax-Waveguide transducer

description.text: This is a customizable waveguide adapter. You can select from WR112 to WR28 standard flanges, Its for SMA type adapters.

The part has to be metallized after printing , using a copper liquid or similar. Be carefull that the connection between inner and outer part to the shield of the SMA are low impedance.
Some tests are in progress, I will provide some results and measurements later.
On the parameters: You can set the diameter of the SMA Adapter dielectricum and in addition the wall size for the hole object. The position of the mounting holes are choosen from a datatable for standard flanges.
Fixing the SMA Adapter is still a problem, there are adapters using mouning holes, which might be better than the shown (I can only glue it after contacting...) -- to be solved.
If you find a problem let me know. Its just the beginning of a new possibility for 3d prints.

comments.text: Would lining the cavity and flange with copper tape be adequate?

comments.text: Yes thats usually best, but as the waves are reflected from the metal surface only, its possible to metalize the the print and it works also, though not being pefect due to the rough surface. The horn antenna linked also uses the same prinziple by metalizing. Also some commercial plastic waveguides using a metal surface do work.

description.text:
i got tired of after a couple prints the clips would get loose due to heat and allow the glass bed to move around every clip i tryed had that issue so i put all of my knowledge and diffrent styles from various makers together to get these they fit my qidi 6x9 bed perfect and going strong with no looseness after a week of printing

main design came from ChrisX35 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1596076

and i elongated as seen in some other clip designs for other printers and ended up with these they should do the trick after much wasted plastic on other designs thanks to all of the makers that have designed qidi glass clips i have a little of everyones design in these

as a side note my glass is exactly 6x9 if u have one smaller then that u may have to extend the overlaps to make up the difference or make them taller for 1/4 inch glass as mine is 1/8

i use some small computer screws to attach the sides after using the holes in the corners to mount it with the bed screws

description.text:
Get started racing quadcopters with this simple and durable frame.

Printable on 200mm x 200mm bed.

87g with 50% infill ABS. Used ABS slurry, but PEI sheet is better.

250-400g AUW with battery, depending on your build.

kiloohm.com

Printer:

Davinci 1.0 with Repetier mod

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.02mm

Infill:

Experiment. 20-50% works. Maybe use less.
Designed in Autodesk Inventor Pro 2016. Simply layed out a basic 2d square, added arms and extruded it out then applied fillets.

• Project Name: Race quad
• Overview & Background: Maybe you have a computer club at school or physics class that needs a project. Cost of drone parts $200-300. Cost of video (fpv) costs $100-200
• Objectives: Hands on project
• Audiences: ages 15-99
• Subjects: Physics, Aeronautics, Robotics
• Skills Learned (Standards): You will learn applied electronics, aeronautics and RF theory.
• Lesson/Activity: Build as a group or several at a time, discuss theory and operation as you go.
• Duration: 8-16 hours
• Preparation: Student should have a basic knowledge of electrical circuits, physics and a level of maturity and knowledge of safety procedures to not get their fingers cut off.

-recommended parts
4", 5", 6", prop ready
Cobra or Sunnysky 2204 2300kv
KISS 30a or DYS, mini esc mounted vertically in arm slot. Or all-in one ESC in center, qbrain. Blheli + oneshot.
Frsky X4R-SB with Taranis
Acro Naze32 or Afro mini, borisB beta flight and accelerometer disabled.
Pololu 5v 600mah Stepdown
PZ0420m 5V 600TVL Mini Camera
DTF/Hawkeye 5.8ghz 200mw video, or Lumeneer Race band 5.8
HQ Prop 6x4.5 or Dal 5045 bull nose prop
Nanotech 1000mah 4S 45C battery, or 3S if you want a milder ride

• References: Drone University by John Glover (me): http://amazon.com/Drone-University-John-M-Glover/dp/0692316035

Text_Font = write/orbitron.dxf

These are parts to a camera mount for the RotorX Atom V1. This is an adjustable angle camera mount. This replaces the front standoffs and the holes are sized for an M2 tap, spaced to fit the holes on the Atom frame. It fits the normal tiny 600tvl cameras used on the Atom. The height of this mount is specific to my build but should work for others with minor modification by shortening the height or using washers/spacers to achieve the height of your build. The height is 25.5mm. Part 2 has holes on the ends sized for an M2 tap. Part 2 fits into part 1 and uses M2 screws to secure the camera angle, although the parts I had printed fit nice and tight and don't really need the screws to secure the angle.

I edited this part to make it more print friendly, although may still be a tough print with a filament printer. I had the part printed by SLS by Shapeways and it came out fantastic.

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text:
I designed this because I was sick of having all my tools laying on my desk. My OCD kicked in I guess. If you want to customize for your own needs, I have uploaded the SolidWorks Part File, STEP, and IGES.

Overall size is 200mm x 75mm x 20mm.

Designed to Hold:

• 4 SD Cards
• 2 Elmer's Glue Sticks
• Tweezers
• Scraper
• Exacto Knife and Blades
• Oiler Syringe
• Screwdriver and Bits
• 6" Calipers
• 4 Extra Nozzles
• Super Glue
• Space for Random Bolts/Nuts, etc

To install, I am just using Double Sided Tape and sticking to the side of the Robo.

UPDATE

Printing Holders now instead of using Double Sided Tape. The tape was holding but its not as secure as I would like. I will post the files after I confirm they work.

The print just failed and now I am waiting on replacement parts for my Robo. Will update as soon as I am back up and running.

UPDATE

I finished the Hangers and they are working better than expected. Plus they look pretty cool!

I also loaded another Revision of the Tool Holder basically just moving some stuff around to better organize.

Robo 3D

No

Microscope slide dividers for anyone who wants to create custom microscope slide boxes/cassettes of all sizes- ranging from pocket sized to gigantic multi-layered containers.

As the name implies, the Slide Holder (A4).stl fits any A4-sized box. Print 4 of these to accommodate up to 82 slides. I've also uploaded the Slide Holder Unit.stl for anyone who wants to customize it using your favorite 3D modelling program (sorry, no .scad file!). Blend files are available for Blender 3D users. Use an array to multiply the units at +1 unit (or +5mm) offset along the fat arm of the "L".

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 microns

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This model fits most standard Prusa i3 printer. Just rotate the model 45 degrees around the Z-axis. Depending on your arrangement skills you can print up to 4 A4 sized holders at a time.This print requires a perfectly levelled bed, so make sure you do proper levelling, as well as bed cleaning. Do not use rafts or skirts. Learn to clean your bed and set the temps right for adequate adhesion.

IMPORTANT:
Note that in slicing using Craftware, set a Vertical shell offset of -0.07 to the inside to ensure that the slides would fit. Tweak an equivalent setting when using other slicers.

Print may require removal of strings in between the 'teeth'. Personally, printing two models placed side by side (at a 45 degree angle rotation) works best to minimize "inter-tooth" travels, and subsequently, stringing.

title: Scalar - Hot End cooling system upgrade

description.text:
Description

These parts increase the cooling of AllInOne Heatsink.

The 5015S turbine is reused from the original design of the AllInone Hotend holder.
The turbine is now cooling down the heatsink of the hot end instead of the small 25mm fan.

Fan Holders

We provide 3 types of fan holder:

  • AllInOne (25mmFanShroud.stl): The 25mm fan is reused to cool down the PLA printed part.
  • E3D (30mmFanShroud.stl): the 30mm fan can be reused to cool down the PLA printed part.
  • E3D Volcano (30mmFanShroud_Volcano.stl), the 30mm fan is also reused, but the fan shroud output is lower than the E3D version.

What this design can fix

This design can fix some cases where some type of filaments will expand inside the hotend as the heatsink body near the heat block is getting hot due to lack of airflow.

Updates:

  • 2016.07.015 - Add Blower_Fan_Holder_V5, this model has a direct airflow toward the bottom of the hotend heatsink. the V4 was intended to push the airflow up.
  • 2016.07.02 - Fix 25mm fan holder, the bottom was not flat

Have a great printing experience.

3D Modular Systems
Evolutive 3D Printers

You enjoy it and want to help us with a donation: https://www.paypal.me/3DMS

http://www.3dmodularsystems.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/3dmodularsystem
Youtube: http://www.youtube.com/c/3DModularSystems3DPrinters

title: Knife-shaped Key Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Look also at the new version http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1810411

There are two versions of the key holder.
The first version is for up to nine keys and the second version for up to five keys.

Parts for version one :
1x key holder_1.stl , 1 x key holder_2.stl , 2x standoff_9 keys.stl , 1x locking disc_9 keys.stl , 1x keychain.stl and spacer.stl to prevent the rattle if less than nine keys are installed (For example 2 spacer if you only have seven keys).
3x M3x20 countersink screw (DIN 965) , 3x M3 locknut , 1x M3 washer.

Parts for version two :
1x key holder_1.stl , 1 x key holder_2.stl , 2x standoff_5 keys.stl , 1x locking disc_5 keys.stl , 1x keychain.stl and spacer.stl if needed (For example 2 spacer if you only have seven keys).
3x M3x14 countersink screw (DIN 965) , 3x M3 locknut , 1x M3 washer.

The part key holder_1.stl needs support.
I printed key holder_1.stl and key holder_2.stl with HDglass from Formfutura and 0,175 Layer height, for the standoff and the locking disc I used ApolloX from from Formfutura but you can also use ABS.​

https://youtu.be/AG3s51Lnb9o

Enjoyment

Pour yourself a nice cold drink, sit back and relax.

The platform

I imported the original platform stl file into NX 10 and started a sketch on the same plain as the flat side. Using the original as a guide, I recreated the geometry. Its not exactly the same because I kind of gave up after the first decimal place of guessing dimensions. There shouldn't be any noticeable differences between the two, except the missing logo in the middle.

The castle base

The base is not modified in any way, shape or form and is simply uploaded it here to have a complete set. It was designed by WRITEMEDIA and I by no means take credit for the design of Castle.STL.

This is a jig used to sand the heads of M5 bolts / Screws down so they can sit on top of small bearings such as the mr105zz.

I have included the freecad file if you want to modify it to accommodate different sized bolts / screws.

print_settings.Notes:: Also the "mof5_fixed.stl" model should be slightly rotated in z (by ~2.5 degrees) to stand perpendicular to the print bed. Not sure why it's slightly off.

description.text:
This is a unit-cell of MOF-5, probably the most famous metal-organic framework material. The cell is cubic microscopically, which is what the model represents.

Macroscopically, the material is still cubic (see pictures below)

Work in progress. Not exactly easy to print.

Printer:

M3D

Resolution:

High

Infill:

8.75% (med.)

Notes:

The .stl will need to be scaled up. I use 50x in all 3 dimensions.

"mof5_better.stl" has higher resolution but will probably take longer to print.

Also the "mof5_fixed.stl" model should be slightly rotated in z (by ~2.5 degrees) to stand perpendicular to the print bed. Not sure why it's slightly off.

MOF-5 unit cell. The yellow sphere is the volume of a single pore of the crystal. Larger (~ 40 micrometer) MOF-5 crystals. These are the same size as many micro-organisms. I recommend printing the supports in a different color and/or material if possible.

description.text: I enjoy watching Netflix on my iPad, especially when my wife is watching "Dancing with the Stars"! I got tired of cupping my hand over the speaker and decided to design one that is form fitting. I know there are several on Thingiverse now, this one was created mid 2011. update, I bought my wife a new iPad 4 and it fits perfectly!

All parts were printed on a TOM with a MK6+. My settings were: Object infill% 35, Layer height(mm) .32, Number of shells 0, feedrate (mm/s) 32. Print the part. Clean up any sharp edges with sandpaper. Enjoy louder audio! I've uploaded a new repaired STL file

title: Kenmore/Whirlpool Handle Bracket for Stainless (alum) handle

description.text:
UPDATED .STL FILES FOR BETTER FIT 06/30/16.
TWO NEWER VERSIONS, BETTER FIT.

I have a Kenmore 106.72153111 23 CUFT refrigerator in stainless steel.
I has nice brushed aluminum handles, but one end (of each) has a poorly designed gray plastic bracket. Mine both broke after about a year, and I have re-glued them numerous times.
You cannot just buy the plastic part. You have to buy the whole metal handle too. As of now Jun 2016, that is about an $80 -$85 price for one of the two handles.
I finally decided to make my own. Not perfect but close enough. If these break I will update the design a bit. (part of W10564292)

This part (part of WPW10564292) should also fit a Whirlpool WRT311F2BM00 refrigerator.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.03mm

Infill:

50% rectilinear

Notes:

I used Gizmo Dorks Transparent ABS. My favorite. I wish the same formulation came in other colors.

You will have to add your own supports. I used Simplify3D and used the auto support feature and removed a lot of the support to insure I could get the out easily. The ones up the center where the screw goes to attach to the aluminum hand were fairly sparse. Ones near the side walls do not need to be removed if you can get the screw and driver in there.

On my second shot I reduced the outer layers, top and bottom from 3 to 2 to speed up the print. I think 3 layers is better and costs about five minutes. My print time was about 1 hour.

I reduced the squash on the first layer from 90% to 95% because the rdius edge gets mess up on the first layer.

Clean up the mounting holes and make sure the screw heads that attach the braker to the door are flush with the bracket as much as you can. Make sure the screw that holds the plastic bracket can fit through the hole at the back of the cavity.

The photo included here is not actually the same as the design. The two bumps on the "T" protrusion which fit into the brushed aluminum handle can be tight. You can file or trim the two small bumps on the "T". Or, place the bracket flat side down on a hard surface, and press the aluminum part onto the plastic "T" with just some gentle pressure straight down.
I used Helix Modeling 5.1 from Microcadam c. 2001. No longer available -- a travesty!

remixed_from.author: linearchaos
remixed_from.title: Blanking Plate for the module bay on a Turnigy 9XR RC Transmitter

description.text:
A few minor tweaks to make the blanking plate fit in a Taranis instead of a 9xr/9xr pro, and a (slightly generous) hole punched for the Banggood 4-in-1 Multimodule's bind button. OpenSCAD source the likes of which would make your mother cry is included if you want to put more holes in it, or take some out. I don't judge.

Prints in PLA.

Edit 2016-06-15: Added a module case for the Banggood 4-in-1 Module because it was flopping around on the pins entirely too much for my comfort. Some M2 x 10-12 screws, some M2 nuts and 2mm metal screws (again, scrounge around) and it's snug as a bug and works just fine in my Taranis. The blanking plate on its own is still good for stuff like the Spektrum Hack module or anything else that uses the correct female headers, but these bottom-insert surface mount female headers on the banggood module just don't inspire a lot of confidence.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

Shouldn't matter

Notes:

This ends up printing as pretty much solid with my slicer, 3 bottom layers, 4 infill, and 3 top layers, and the walls are more or less solid. It's pretty firm, but if the wall thickness is dialed back too much it just snaps clean from the baseplate the first time you put it in the bay.

The module box should be printed with fairly thin side walls to allow the nubs to get squeezed in and release the box. Too thick and PLA will crack or split on a layer line, too thin and it won't have any structure.

title: Rostock Max V2 7" LCD Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a screen mount that fits onto the side of my SeeMeCNC Rostock Max V2. The side is covered by a blank on new printers. I removed the balnk and placed this screen mount in its place.
It can also replace the LCD on the front of the printer.

The screen is a 7" LCD with a SSD1960 controller. Any cheap model from eBay will fit as they all appear to be the same part. I got mine from Amazon in the US.

I no longer have a Raspberry Pi running OctoPrint inside the base of my printer.

I recently upgraded to a Duet WiFi with a PanelDue and this is now the only screen mounted on the printer.

FYI: The green parts are "Rostock Max V2 - Triple Strong Bed Clamp - No hardware needed!" by Artesian and can be found HERE

author: timbalish

title: Monoprice Select Mini X-Axis Sheet Metal Spacer

description.text:
The sheet metal panel shrouding the top, back, and bottom of the X-axis gantry of the Monoprice Select Mini is often loose and can rattle during printing. The root cause of this issue is a severely undersized spacer between the Z-axis block and X-axis sheet metal panel, located just behind the X-axis limit switch. This part replaces that undersized spacer.

It can be installed without any disassembly, but installation is much easier if you remove the front panel of the upper chassis. See disassembly guide here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1HJaLIcUD4oiIUYu6In7Bxf7WxAOiT3n48RvOe5pvSHk/edit?usp=sharing

comments.text: On my Select Mini (shipped November 2016), the white under-sized spacer has been replaced with a black, appropriately sized spacer.  The home switch is affixed to the sheet metal above, not a small metal tab below.  So this doesn't seem to be the fix for the awful noises during traverses in X for my machine :(

title: Custom Web Cam Conversion Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A customizable web cam conversion mount to retrofit a thin tube neck style halogen desk lamp with a Logitech C210 camera.

Printer:

Ord Bot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

0.2

Notes:

Print in ABS or PLA. Edit the OpenScad file to customize if you are using a different camera.
Designed in OpenScad.

KEEP the screws and the long pin taken from the original Logitech C210 web cam mount, and re-use them with this mount.

In this project, a halogen desk lamp was repurposed into a web cam stand. The lamp neck measured 6mm in diameter. This new mount has a 6mm clip which attaches the camera to the lamp.

The project includes the following printed parts:

  • camera mount
  • camera data cable clips

.

  • Print (1) camera clip mount
  • Print (3) or more wire clips

Remove the small screw from the logitech mount, and then push the long hinge pin out of the logitech mount with a paper clip. Push hard!

Trim the extra square flashing off of the long hinge pin so that it is rounded. Reinstall the long hinge pin into the new mount after lining it up with the C210 web cam base.

Parts required:
.

  • Logitech C210 web cam
    http://support.logitech.com/en_us/product/webcam-c210

  • Halogen desk lamp (had this on hand.. it was an annoying lamp with only 1 brightness level)
    http://fandangolighthouse.com/brand-dainolite/halogen-desk-lamp/dlha111-sv/sku-25V0H

    .
    Enjoy!

At the Minneapolis Institute of Art are a small number of plaster casts dating back to the days when the museum first opened. I was delighted when I found out that a full-sized cast of Michelangelo's "Pitti Tondo" was among the casts in an area not normally open to the public. The guard who told me about the tondo helped secure access for a short time so I could photograph it to model it later.

So here is my model of Michelangelo's "Pitti Tondo" based on a plaster cast.

I took 24 photos with my Sony Alpha 5100 on a tripod. The settings were: ISO 100, f/8, using manual focus on a Nikon Series E 35mm 1:2.8 lens mounted via an adapter to my Sony. I shot all the photos in RAW format.

At home, I made tone and color corrections in Lightroom, then exported the resulting corrected photos as 8-bit TIFs. In Photoscan I used the 'Medium' setting at each step. I discovered I hadn't photographed the top or bottom rims of the tondo, so I took the finished OBJ file into Meshmixer and extruded the rear of the tondo to create a flat surface and fix the missing surfaces elsewhere. Hopefully the tondo will print better than most of the models I've shared before.

comments.text: @ 3DWP Thanks! I have hopes of getting better photos next time to really drill down and capture the fine tool marks that I could see on the cast. I was so pressed for time that I took just enough photos to get the overall tondo, but I would have liked to get more photos of the finer details in closer shots.
comments.author: jerry7171

comments.text: Very nice work!

"Classic" bathtub stopper, printed in ABS. It actually works, although I wouldn't expect it to hold overnight. Thin ABS is somewhat flexible, but not as good as latex. You could try printing it on more flexible material and see how it does.

My new YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCnnw56J_TeOsF4M_F5pPPJQ Have you been envious of ever-dimensionally-increasing build platforms? Well now you can claim to be able to print ONE FOOT* OF PLASTIC!
  • Warning: Claim may be pun.
    • But seriously though, this was a test print while I continually try to get my printer to meet my unrealistically high quality expectations. Hope you get a kick out of this! UPDATE:
    I added an approximately "full-size" model of just the top half of the foot. I'm satisfied with the quality.
Print, glue, admire.

description.text: This robotic hand was created using the 4M Robotic Hand Kit, 5 servos, a 3D-printed servo bracket, and EZ-Robot's EZ-B robot controller.

Printer:

PowerSpec Ultra 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

medium

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I used PLA filament.

After building the 4M Robotic Hand, I decided to have EZ-Robot's EZ-B controller move the fingers and thumb using servos and pieces of string. I created the servo bracket in AutoCAD and printed it on my printer.

You'll need:

4M Robotic Hand Kit
5 standard-size servos
EZ-Robot EZ-B robot controller
Some string like the one in the kit
Screws, nuts, and washers.

Cut 5 pieces of string about 12 inches or 31 cm long.
Thread string through the finger tips and the fingers.
Install fingers in the hand frame.
Print the servo bracket.
Put the servo bracket on the hand frame.
Drill holes in the hand frame for screws, nuts, and washers.
Install servos in servo bracket.
Install servo bracket on hand frame using screws, nuts, and washers.
Run EZ-Builder and create a new project that have 5 horizontal servo controls.
After configuring servo controls, move servos to 1.
Install horns so that they point at the fingers.
Install screws on horns.
Tie strings to horn screws.
Move servos to move fingers and thumb.

This project is a multi-discipline project that requires students to understand how to design and print 3D images using proper software. They will research real world material prices and compute how much it would cost to build their dream house as well as paint its surface.

Tips and Tricks

Be sure to check all shapes available within the Geometric and Shape Generator tabs. Utilize all available resources that the software provides for you.

Focus on the house and pool first before adding extremities such as lights and bushes if your group would like.

Overview and Background

This project is a multi-discipline project that requires students to understand how to design and print 3D images using proper software. They will research real world material prices and compute how much it would cost to build their dream home as well as paint its surface.

Objectives

Students will practice area and surface area while finding real world pricing

Audiences

This project is intended for 7th graders.

Subjects

Math, Computer Science, English, Technology, Construction, Art

Skills Learned (Standards)

CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.7.G.B.6
Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, volume and surface area of two- and three-dimensional objects composed of triangles, quadrilaterals, polygons, cubes, and right prisms.

Lesson/Activity

Students will be taken to the computer lab and will be assigned to a group of three. Each student will be responsible for a job title. Instructions can be found on the project hand out.

Duration

Students will be given class time to work on this project for one week.

Preparation

Students will have already learned and applied the formulas for area and surface area. Students will also be familiar with the program Tinkercad and given access to a computer to research material prices.

References

The students will be required to research material prices during the project.

Rubric and Assessment

Rubric and Assessment can be found on the student handout.

Handouts:

Name __ Date ___

                                       Build-a-Property

Congratulations! You just bought a plot of land to start life anew. It’s your job to build your dream home and yard. But here’s the catch, how much will this all cost?

Assign Roles:
Contractor: Your job is to design your dream house in Tinkercad! Make it creative! Ideas you might want to include: a pool, moat, multiple towers/buildings etc.
Storyline: Create a description of your plot of land.
Researcher: How much would it cost to build your house and paint it?

Project Directions:
1) Create a new design in Tinkercad and name your property.
2) Discuss with your group. What should appear on your property?
3) Design and print your 3D images.
4) Create a poster board of your plot of land! Make sure your description is visible on the
poster board. Be creative!
5) Research possible materials and paint you would use to build your house. Answer the
accompanying questions on the student handout!

Rubric:

This project is out of 50 points.

10 pts each:

Group Work:
___ Group worked well together during class time

Question Points
__ Questions are complete and correct

Poster Points
__ 3D figures are printed correctly
__ Poster is colorful and organized
__ Poster contains the description of your plot

Questions:

What shapes do you see in your plot of land?

2)

How much material would be required to build your house?

From your answer in part a, how much would it cost? Provide a link to where you will buy the material.

3)

How much paint would be needed to color the outside of your house?

From your answer in part a, how much would it cost? Provide a link to where you will buy the material.

remixed_from.author: kodera2t
remixed_from.title: 8 to 12 GHz Horn antenna with Coax-Waveguide transducer

description.text:
This is a customizable horn antenna with the a flange generated from WR112 to WR28. Needs to be metalized to function (or metal casted).  
Attention: The customizer shows reversed face, the resulting stl works. Openscad does not show this problem.

Select the proper WR code, and in addition to this you can define some parameters as length of the wavguide (from the flange border) till the horn starts. The horn has an opening for a optimal horn (based on http://www.ece.mcmaster.ca/faculty/nikolova/antenna_dload/current_lectures/L18_Horns.pdf),
Its a work in progress, I didnt test the results yet other than printability. Please feedback also if I did a mistake in the formulars.
Before econnecting to a waveguide adapter, metalize the surface and check that the impendance is low for the inner sides and the flange plane.

comments.text: It looks like the waveguide flange table assumes all waveguides have height = 1/2 width. That is usually but not always true, for example WR90 has height 0.4" and not 0.45".  So there was a small mismatch with a real metal waveguide, when I printed out a WR90 flange using the customizer.
comments.author: jbeale

comments.text: Very nice design! I printed out a small horn with WR75 flange and it fit correctly on the waveguide, and worked as expected after adding copper tape to the inner surfaces.

description.text: This is the extruder used on Aluminum Mendel http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16076. It combines the features of its ancestors that I liked best. It provides more internal filament support than the standard body for less filament buckling. Changeover is very fast.

All items will print without support except the cam. Print body and idler mount in ABS, PLA won't take the heat.  I added heat sinks because the X carriage is very narrow in this design without much area to dissipate heat .  They are not totally necessary, but do help when using high extruder temperatures.

title: MM3 Fan Duct for dual extruder

description.text:
I tried the standard fan ducts for the MM3 but they blow a long way from the nozzles and make the blower fans stick out - so I designed this.
Best to print this in ABS as it's going to be very close to the nozzles. At the moment the blower fans just sit in place without any security - so far even with vigorous x-y movement they stay on - but I will modify this so that we can use cable ties or screws.
I have been testing this duct for about two weeks and it seems to be working very well. The only thing I don't like is that you cannot see the nozzles very well to examine how the print is going - some trust required. It does encourage me to walk away more - rather than standing there staring at the print.

description.text:
This a remix of www.thingiverse.com/thing:1598280 by micahstevens
I rounded off the end of his design. It is a door latch for the front door of the QIDI printer. Put one under each end of the handle on the front door, and the magnets will hold the door closed.

Printer:

QIDI

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Printed in PLA with 3 top, 3 bottom, and 3 outside layers

Assembly

Install 6mm diameter x 1.5mm thick X 2 per latch. Press them in and then glue them. Note: I got the magnets at http://www.ebay.com/itm/251471137493 for $7/100 w/ free shipping. I've seen these at qty 200 for $5 lately. After the magnets are in place a little glue can help them stay there. I’ve had fun using “Bondic”. It’s a high viscosity, UV activated instant catalytic cure cyanoacrylate. A few drops from the oiler like pen the glue comes in, then flip the pen around and zap it with the UV LED light, wait 10 seconds and your good to go. Plus you can fill gaps / build up layers of this stuff as needed. Not the cheapest, but pretty cool for glue. Here is a link http://www.ebay.com/itm/301662153693

Unscrew the door handle's two mounting screws and re-use them to hold the latch assy's in place. Re assemble the door handle with the latches and you're done.

Tweaks

If you want to modify this puppy, it is on Tinkercad at: https://tinkercad.com/things/h2lI5ci37vj

print_settings.Notes:: IMPORTANT: For the side latch buckle, print the female part with internal supports otherwise it won't print well. After printing, knock out the supports with a small screwdriver and cleanup excess plastic with an Xacto knife.

description.text:
Lost in the wilderness? A few feet of paracord for making a bow drill fire set or for a thread to fish with might save you. This bracelet gives you 7 feet of paracord right on your wrist. Both styles of buckle are remixes of designs used for nylon webbing. The paracord is available in many colors from Home Depot for about $3 for 50 feet. The total cost to make a survival bracelet is less than $1 per bracelet. Whether you are new or old to 3D printing, this is a fun and useful project which you can complete in less than an hour.

Update: I've included a design for a side latch buckle. Now there are two styles of buckle to choose from. Be sure to use supports for side latch buckle female prints.

Once you print the male and female buckles, space them at about 7.5 - 8 inches apart at the openings and follow the photos for weaving the paracord. IMPORTANT: Be sure that each successive knot alternates which side goes under the two main cords. You must alternate back and forth otherwise the bracelet will have a twist in it. When you finish the final knot, trim the cords and lightly melt the ends with a lighter to keep them in place.

ALSO IMPORTANT: For the side latch buckle, print the female part with internal supports otherwise the print will fail. After printing, knock out the supports with a small screwdriver and cleanup excess plastic with an Xacto knife.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Be sure to use 100% infill to make the buckle sturdy. I used PLA but ABS would last longer. I didn't have to do any post processing to get the buckle to operate. All clearances seem to be good.

Extruder 200C
Bed 60C on Kapton

IMPORTANT: For the side latch buckle, print the female part with internal supports otherwise it won't print well. After printing, knock out the supports with a small screwdriver and cleanup excess plastic with an Xacto knife.

description.text:
Update 16 Sep 2016 As user "FernandoGarcia" and I also found, the pressure of the spring could cause the thin heated bed to bow down slightly. This is not a big problem because I print on glass and the glass does not bow, but this could lead to the edges of the glass not heating properly. The original model, had a support underneath but was difficult to clean up as it needed supports. So for those printing the newer version, you can also print 4 of these - bbSpringClampFixer.stl and glue them to the bottom before fixing as shown. No supports needed. This will force the PCB bed up to the glass. Also if the height difference is too much, just sand the bottom of bbSpringClampNewVersion.stl to get closer tolerance and fit more snugly(see image)

Update 24 Aug 2016 As user "piggei" suggested, here is a newer version. Not As nice looking but much stronger and easier to print. No supports needed as well. Just print 4 as is(upside down) and fix as usual right side up.

Update - 23/06/2016 - Added the Sketchup files for modding as per users request. Note that the STL's from these models are not manifold. After modding, use netfabb or some online service to "Fix" the STL before printing.

Saw these and decided to modify them to suit my printer. These clips now fit the Geeetech Aluminium printer which has a Borosilicate 3mm glass plate over the MK2A heat bed.
They also facilitate removal of the glass for cleaning/removing stuck prints without disturbing the bed level.

The spring effect keeps the glass in place without moving and is pretty easy to slip the glass back in place.
Also no more problems with the head banging on the clips etc. as this is designed to be level with the glass.

Printer:

Geeetech Full Metal Aluminum

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed in PLA and works with no problems at the heat of 55 degrees C. If you plan to use ABS then print this with ABS. But for PLA this works fine.

Make sure you clean out ALL the supports especially in the Rt. Angle corner inside so the heated bed fits properly and the screw holes line up.
The spring will fit inside the hole and will not be squeezed.

title: Pibow Coupé Case Bracket For Lulzbot Mini

description.text:
20160609: I updated the STL file so that the mounting bracket can accommodate the brackets for the popular plexiglass enclosure you can find on eBay and Amazon for the Mini. If you're not using it, then it doesn't affect you. But that's what the "random slot" is for. The pics of the green bracket is from version 1. They're still useful as the mounting process remains the same. The yellow bracket is the updated version 2 which lets the enclosure bracket fit. They're functionally identical beyond the notch and some minor structural and tolerance improvements.

This is a small bracket that allows you to attach a Raspberry Pi in a Pibow 3 Coupé case to the side of a Lulzbot Mini. The benefit here is that you can run OctoPrint on the Pi that's tucked out of the way on the side of the Mini.

The bracket-to-Pi side uses 2.5mm nylon bolts. The bracket-to-Mini side uses 3mm nylon bolts. You should avoid anything metal because the screws are in close proximity to electronics of both the Pi and the Mini.

With the Pi mounted in that location, you can use the Lulzbot Mini Raspberry Pi Camera Mount and an 18" flex camera cable to get your Pi camera comfortably viewing your build area.

I chose this particular case because it gives me easy access to the Display-O-Tron Pi Hat, which you can use to stream system information from OctoPrint to your display (or anything else you're interested in seeing).

You probably need a micro USB cable with a 90 degree connector to make sure you have clearance to power the Pi.

description.text:
I like flat cat5 cables for when I travel. They save a lot of space over conventional cables. And I have a couple from some D-Link IP cameras that are "free" since i used other cables for those cameras.

On our last trip I thought there has to be a neater way to stow this cable so I don't risk breaking the spring tabs when I'm pulling it out of my luggage. This is similar to how a retractable cable works, but it's manual. just wrap it around and plug in your RJ45s, Hope this helps you out.

My nozzles were not aligned to correct height... Things got a bit warpy.
But, I CAN print it in great form. (and will soon)

Imported jpeg logo into Cura twice, once for 'dark as higher', once for 'light as higher' with no smoothing, .3 mm tall, base .1mm tall. I exported as STLs.

Next I started slic3r on Mac (ugh it doesn't have the features Windows does). I imported and corrected the STL and exported as OBJs.

From Cura, I imported the OBJs and printed at .3 layer height, 0.4 shell width, 1.6mm top/bottom layer. 0.05 overlap on dual extrusion.

To fix this up, I will set my heatbed to 70C and put 10kilogram on it for a few hours.
Then flip it and do again. That will smooth both sides. (A flat large skillet with wax paper also works well. Heat it, set design on wax paper, pull it off before the wax paper catches fire. Hide the skillet because it has burned wax all over it.)

I tried to put together the best design elements of few other spool holders published on this website and created my own universal spool holder for K8400. It can hold spools with hole diameters from 30mm to 62mm. The maximum spool height depends on the hole size - the wider holes allow to fit higher spools. With maximum hole size of 62mm, spool height can reach 120mm.
For this holder I designed my own thread with 45 degree sides that allow printing it clean without support.
The holder is attached to the original mounting piece of K8400. It uses 2 plain 608 bearings and one M8 self-locking nut (all parts of the original K8400's spool holder).
The only piece you need to purchase is M8x120mm bolt. It will replace the shorter (M8x70mm) bolt that came with the printer. New bolt can be fully threaded or, like in my case, may have only 20mm long thread at the end.

UPDATE
Check also my filament ballast that can be used with this holder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1887621

UPDATE 25-Dec-2017 Uploaded big-nut_rev2.stl with cutouts that reduce overall weight of the thing.

UPDATE 13-Feb-2018 Created the brake to address smoothness of this holder: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2792583

RepRap

Printer:

K8400 VERTEX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 and 0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I recommend printing big-bolt.stl and cover.stl files with 0.1 resolution. Other 2 files can be printed with 0.2mm resolution. I used 100% infill, but this is most likely overkill. You can experiment with lower numbers and share with us which value worked for you.
I used 7mm wide brim with all parts except the cover piece. I print all parts directly on the glass and use hairspray as adhesion. It takes several hours to print big-bolt and big-nut and on my 1st try both pieces slightly pilled of the glass, however both were still usable. You may consider gluing down the brim with super glue while printing.

Assembly

1) Before assembling the holder make sure big-nut piece can be easily put on big-bolt piece, that it rotates freely and can reach the very bottom of the thread. Depending on the quality of your printer and filament it may work right away or require cleaning/sanding.
2) Remove the original spool holder from printer's side panel and disassemble it. You will reuse 2 bearings and 1 self-locking nut from it.
3) Replace M8x70mm bolt with M8x120mm bolt - put it through the mounting piece. Do not attach it to the printer yet. Put the mounting piece on the desk with the bolt thread facing up.
4) Place one bearing on the bolt and place big-bolt piece on top of it with the wider side facing down. The bearing should easily move inside the hole of the big-bolt.
5) Place the tube piece on M8x120 bolt. It will act as a spacer between 2 bearings.
6) Place the second bearing on M8x120 bolt and slide it into big-bolt all the way until it lays on the top of the tube piece.
7) Place self-locking nut on M8x120 bolt and tighten it. Make sure not to over-tighten the nut. Big-bolt should not move along M8x120 bolt, but at the same time should freely rotate.
8) Place the cover piece on the top of big-bolt. Its only purpose is to hide the nut.
9) Attach the holder assembly to the printer. Big-bolt has 4 cutouts that are aligned with the positions of mounting screws.
10) Place the spool on the holder and tighten it with big-nut.

author: Bespalov

description.text:
Vanguard_JT AR-15 Receiver

Author

JT

Version

1.1

Description

The Vanguard_JT is an AR15 lower receiver designed to withstand as many rounds as possible. The Vanguard_JT was modeled from the Vanguard by shadowfall.

The 45 degree cut of the magwell was originally designed so that the lower could be printed at a 45 degree angle to eliminate the need for support material. Printing at a 45 degree angle is not recommended. It was found that printing the lower at a 45 degree angle will lead to the buffer tube tower breaking in only a few shots. The 45 degree cut in the magwell was kept because it allowed for magazines to be inserted more efficiently.
The buffer tube tower was thickened and lengthened to increase durability. The castle nut and buttstock tube lock are not needed on the Vanguard_JT because of its lengthened buffer tube tower.
*The front take-down pinhole was widened to improve durability.

Note: The Vanguard JT went to version 1.1 with the inclusion of an updated version by FP. The updates are enumerated in the changelog v1.1 section of this readme file. For now both versions are included while we test.

Instructions

Print at a horizontal orientation as seen in renders
Depending on quality of print, screwing the buffer tube into the buffer tube tower may be difficult. Applying heat to the buffer tube from the inside with a miniature blow torch or equivalent eases screwing in the buffer tube.
Depending on quality of print, it is likely that all holes will need to be drilled out to the correct size
For assembly, Snap Pins (included with files) or 1/4-20 machine screws with wing nuts are recommended. Since the front take-down pin hole is wider than the rear, there are two Snap Pin files included, a Front Snap Pin and a Rear Snap Pin. Under rapid-fire conditions, the Snap Pins WILL BREAK after around 200 rounds. If using Snap Pins, have extras ready to replace broken Snap Pins.

Changelog v1.1

Receiver was modified to fit a freefloating handguard (by FP).
Moved the front takedown pin and safety detent holes (by FP).
Added cut out for forward assist (by FP).
thinned out buffer tower along y-axis for use with a castle nut (by FP).

The latest in my Doctor Who/Transformers crossover toys!  
The main artistic reference for the Dalek mode was the 2005 season episode 'Dalek', and the amazing WETA sculpture of the Dalek with the shell opened up to show off the interior.  The transformation geometry is original.  I took a little inspiration from the transformer 'Octus', who apparently turns into a Dalek in his alt-mode though that was never shown in the one comic he appeared in.  Octus mostly inspired this design to have multiple arms.  I also took inspiration from the half-human hybrid Dalek Sec from the episode 'Daleks in Manhatten', in having the Kaled Mutant form the head of the model when in robot mode.  
The basic design was done in AutoCAD 2006.  I did redraw the mutant in ZBrush to give it a more blended, organic look.  
This is a much more challenging toy to print and assemble than either of the Tardis transformers I posted.  There are about 100 parts to be printed, several of which have to be glued together.  There are two parts that have to be printed with full support added by your slicer software, and five parts which have small pieces of support already added to the STL files that you will have to cut away after printing.   
No painting is required, provided you stick to the filament color recommendations.  
The original shown here was printed in PLA on my scratch-built Delta style printer.  It takes a total of about 10oz of plastic, mostly gold and black with some silver, grey, and purple.  Total print time on my machine is about 32 hours.  The toy stands about 6 inches tall in Dalek mode, about 13 inches tall in robot mode.  All of the parts are individually small so you should be able to print this on any size printer.  
Update on 10/13:  Changed upperbody_inside left and right to add a small stop to help prevent the dome from rotating forwards when in Dalek mode with the front of the body open.

This is a MUCH more challenging piece to build than my Tardis Transformer.  There are about 100 parts that need to be printed.  2 of them require full support to be turned on when you slice them.  5 more have small pieces of support I've added in that you will need to cut away after printing.  Many of the parts need to be glued together during assembly, and there is one joint which needs a small piece of 1.75mm filament inserted as a hinge.  There is a good chance you will break parts of this while assembling it unless you follow the instructions very carefully.  
I have included an assembly document with many photos showing how to build this.  It's still a challenging build even with that.  
It's also fairly tricky to transform, with many small fiddly bits that are hard to get into exactly the right places.  I am working on putting together a transformation guide.

comments.author: Ellindsey

comments.text: Not sure yet.  Part of the reason I made a simpler version of the Tardis was because the first one was mechanically terrible, easy to break, incapable of standing unsupported, and not holding together well in Tardis mode.  This Dalek is large and complicated, but mechanically it came out very nicely.  It stands unsupported very well, the joints are tight enough for it to hold a pose, and it holds together very well in Dalek mode.  Even though it's large and complicated to make, I'm really happy with the mechanical design.  I might revisit it at some point in the future to make a simpler, smaller version, but I have a few other design projects I have to tackle first.

This is the first DD Liberator release, tested functional on 5/3/2013 and again on 5/5/2013. Design tweaks included from EXP001 and EXP002 experimental results.
Changes from EXP002:
-Barrel locking lug filet added to reduce stress concentration
-.2" hole added to handle to allow assembly without screw. AR-15 grips will fit, but need a .2" hole drilled .4x.4" from corner. Or download DD's modified AR-15 grip. This is done so you don't need a metal screw to hold the grip on.
-SN removed.
-Hammer body firing pin hole reduced to 140mils to improve firing pin concentricity on primer.
-Trigger stiffened.

How to legally assemble the DD Liberator:
-Print (ONLY) the frame sideways (the shortest dimension is the Z axis). USC18 922(p)(2)(A)*: "For the purposes of this subsection (The Undetectable Firearms Act of 1988) - the term 'firearm' does not include the frame or receiver of any such weapon;"
Thus, you can legally print ONLY the frame entirely in plastic, even without 3.7 ounces of steel.

-Once the frame is finished, epoxy a 1.19x1.19x0.99" block of steel in the 1.2x1.2x1.0" hole in front of the trigger guard. Add the bottom cover over the metal if you don't want it to show.

-Once the epoxy has tried, the steel is no longer removable, and is an integral part of the frame. Now your gun has ~6 ounces of steel and is thus considered a 'detectable' firearm. So now you can print all the other parts.

-Print all the other parts.
The barrel must be built up in the z axis.
The springs must be printed flat on their side.
The hammer body should be printed such that the firing pin hole is in the z axis.
The hammer should be printed on its side.
The trigger must be printed on its side.
The spring connecting rod bushing should be printed up in the z axis, to reduce friction.
The spring connecting rod should be printed on its side.
All pins should be printed on their side to take advantage of intralayer strength.

We'll build the trigger first. Take the trigger spring and note that there's a very small lip on one side of the ovular hole. This lip mounts flush to the trigger piece, and gives the spring enough clearance to not drag on the bottom of the inside of the frame. The spring's free ends should point away from the trigger, towards the back of the gun. Mate these two pieces, and then insert into the frame.

Next, we'll build the hammer subassembly. Insert the hammer into the hammer body with the striking cylinder facing the front of the frame. Insert the hammer pin to connect the hammer to the hammer body. Now press both coil springs onto the hammer body. When the hammer is cocked, the coil spring diameter should reduce (not expand). Once both coils are pressed on, pull one of the coil eyelets behind the hammer, and then insert the spring connecting rod into said eyelet. Rest the rod on the hammer. Slide the spring connecting rod bushing over the spring connecting rod, then pull the other spring back and insert the spring connecting rod into the eyelet. Pull the hammer back and make sure everything is working well. Pull the hammer back and drop in the nail and then insert the firing pin bushing concentric to the nail's head. This keeps the nail from falling out when the hammer is cocked. Notice that one side of the firing pin bushing is chamfered... that side faces the hammer.

Next, drop the hammer into the frame. Note that the hammer secures the trigger. Insert three frame pins to secure the hammer body.

Finally, slide the grip onto the frame and insert the grip pin. Your Liberator is now ready to go!

Before firing a barrel, we recommend heating acetone to boiling and treating the barrel for ~30 seconds to decrease the inner diameter friction, which increases barrel life from 1 round to ~10 rounds. Note that we recommend printing multiple barrels and using each only once. Swapping the barrels is simple and fast: rotate the barrel to release the locking cam. Pull up on the barrel. If the barrel cam broke, turn the Liberator upside down to remove the debris. Then drop your new barrel in and rotate it until it locks.

description.text: Created from a Decorative Garden Mushroom using an Artec 3D Scanner. The model has been checked for holes and given a flat base for printing. This STL was pulled from their gallery of models located at http://www.artec3d.com/gallery/3d-models/ This is a terrific print and looks great in Glow-in-the Dark ABS.

This model requires support and as such was picked for a short tutorial on our blog regarding how to setup for printing with support structures. If you are unfamiliar with support or want to see if you can improve your settings take a look at the full write up. Once you take the plunge and learn it, you'll find yourself printing things you hadn't dared before. http://www.protoparadigm.com/2012/01/printing-with-support-extreme-overhangs/ Don't forget to save your used support structures for making ABS Glue

title: Puente de refuerzo-guia para soporte de rollo. Prusa i3

description.text:
Puente que sirve de refuerzo y guia de filamento para el soporte de rollo en una Prusa i3, marco de aluminio. El soporte esta en:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:60720
Hay dos versiones de puente (Abierto y cerrado), para varilla roscada de 6 mm.
Tambien incluyo un accesorio que guia mejor el filamento. Va encajado a presion en la parte central de cualquiera de los refuerzos.
El accesorio-guia mas estrecho es para filamento de 1,75 mm y el mas abierto es para filamento de 3 mm.
Los cilindros adjuntos tienen la finalidad de dar tiempo a que se enfrie la pieza principal. Los llamo "cilindros enfriadores". Si imprimes las guias conjuntamente con otras piezas y son mas altas, los puedes eliminar.

still HOPE....old RAPMAN revived with poor man Bowden like extuder
compare two Prusa I3 corner block ...one original extruder second with Bowden like extruder just hanging above table !! Great difference on the straight edge...
YES RAPMAN LET US DOWN...BIG TIME....
All products have a finite life but learning of BfB's agenda after having spent $4K+ on what I was led to believe was a going product of the first quality that had a future and to have it discontinued less than a year later; replaced by the same machine, but with expensive proprietary supplies, is rude and unprofessional. A classic case of a company being led around by the nose by the marketing department.

I like my machine. Too bad BfB doesn't. All they see is the cash cow in their shiny new $100 cartridges. Same ol' marketing approach made (in)famous by Gillette. Give away the razor and extract the maximum amount of money long term from their customers by selling razor blades to fit it.

Could've done the Right Thing and kept the 3D Touch as a Pro machine for people who don't need hand-holding. A previous statement led us to believe that this would be the case. But, no...

http://www.bitsfrombytes.com/usd/forum/post/axon-30-alpha-1-released#com...

IF this is an April Fool's joke, I'll happily delete this post or at least edit it to be more positive. Of course, the move to a different forum will make anything voiced here become squelched. Nice. Pretty much adds salt in the wound by making this change on April Fool's Day. If there was any question... not happy and feeling rather disrespected. Really unsure about how/what to tell my partner who reluctantly got behind me on this purchase when we didn't have the money and let me invest extra in what I was told was a superior company and product. Don't get me wrong. The product is. Waiting for the other shoe to drop now on discontinuing said support of it, because that is sure to follow, RSN. You know, that old "end of life" crap. I guess I'll just stuff it and not say anything for as long as I can muster. Thanks for putting me in this position. Of course, it was my decision to be gullible, so I guess it's all my fault.

Bloody frakkin' Bites, this does.

CONCLUSION do not trust anyone when buying propriatory 3d printer rather build your own
today very easy The Prusa I3 is a good start...

title: Bubble Trivet cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This trivet shows a bubble pattern, which was adapted of a photograph. It resembles quite exactly the Voroni pattern, just with more rounded shapes. To get a little variety in trivet design I created a rounded square.

My build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft from 6 mm birch plywood using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute. I used a very dark veneer (might have been ebony) on the topside.

A laser cutter might be a good alternative tool to create one like this.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/Haushaltsgegenstaende/Topfuntersetzer for more trivet designs.
I used a random shot of a bubbles. Then I did some photoshopping to tune the details. Then I used Illustrator to trace the pixel image.

title: Case for Electronic Load Battery Capacitor Tester found on eBay

description.text:
I found a simple electronic load and capacitor tester on eBay. It can still be found there by different sellers and seems to be very common in the DIY community.
Found this thing handy and designed a simple case for it. Actually it is more a cover than a case but it works fine for me.
Designed to be printed without supports, only minor or no rework needed after print.
I added holes for 4mm banana plugs (10mm hole)

1) Print the design with low feed rate to not make it too tight(!), It already fits firmly.
0.15 to 0.2mm slices will work fine with a 0.35/0.4mm nozzle.
Use as much fan as you can bevause of some overhang in there.
2) slide in the PCB
3) Mount the 4mm Jacks (10mm hole already in there) and solder the wires
4) Plug in the 12V Power Jack and start using it.

Printer:

K8400

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm to 0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

0.35 or 0.4mm nozzle
Full fan speed because of overhang
PLA works fine.
ABS might end up in a too tight enclosure.
